item.title: Bangladesh-China trade in commercial services: what the numbers reveal
item.description: Bangladesh-China bilateral trade in commercial services increased more than four times over the last two decades, although the volume of trade in commercial services is far below that of merchandise. At present, trade in commercial services with China accounts for less than one-tenth of trade in go

item.title: Mamdani's democratic socialism: A test case for US governance
item.description: Now that the dust has begun to settle after Zohran Mamdani's decisive victory in the New York mayoral election, the question that looms large is whether he can deliver on his ambitious promises as a self-declared democratic socialist. His victory, though confined to one of the world's most diverse

item.title: Regulatory maze chokes growth of agro-processing industry
item.description:
Bangladesh's agro-processing industry, one of the country's most promising growth sectors, is enmeshed in a web of regulatory tangles, costly testing requirements and weak coordination among government agencies, industry leaders say.
"Producers are forced to deal with multiple regulators to

item.title: Tax incentives vs IMF conditionalities
item.description: One of the conditions Bangladesh was to meet for utilising the multilateral lender IMF's US$4.7 billion loan package has been improvement in the country's tax-to-GDP ratio, one of the lowest in the world. Currently, the ratio is 6.6 per cent, which the IMF wants to be raised to 8.4 per cent within

item.title: Turkish military plane with 20 on board crashes In Georgia
item.description: A Turkish C-130 military cargo plane with at least 20 personnel on board crashed in Georgia on Tuesday after taking off from Azerbaijan but the number of casualties and the cause of the incident were not immediately clear. item.title: Ethics, trust, and inclusive growth define Midland Bank's journey
item.description: Midland Bank PLC, a fourth-generation bank in Bangladesh, has attained steady progress through prudent management, ethical values, digital innovation, and a focus on inclusive growth. item.title: ADB may lend $250m for bankrolling budget deficit
item.description: Bangladesh expects US$250 million soon from the Asian Development Bank in credit for bankrolling budget-financing shortfall, officials say, as an ADB mission is now in Dhaka reviewing country position on financial front. item.title: LC margin rules relaxed to ensure Ramadan supply stability
item.description: Bangladesh Bank (BB) has eased the letter of credit (LC) margin requirements to ensure adequate supply and price stability of key essential commodities during the upcoming month of Ramadan. item.title: 700 MHz spectrum auction: Leading mobile operators push for revision of terms
item.description: The country's three leading mobile operators -- Grameenphone, Robi Axiata and Banglalink -- have jointly urged the telecom regulator to revise the terms of the forthcoming 700 MHz spectrum auction, warning that the current framework could discourage investment and impede efforts to expand mobile co

item.title: Government to be held solely liable for any move beyond July Charter: BNP
item.description: The Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) has cautioned that any decision taken by the interim government beyond the scope of the July National Charter will be the government's sole liability. item.title: Volatile credit supply besets blue economy
item.description: Bangladesh's blue-economy-sector financing continues to crumble, reflecting an inconsistent flow of credit and a lack of bankable projects in the country's vast marine and coastal areas. item.title: ICB sees Tk 12b frozen in failed banks, NBFIs
item.description: The Investment Corporation of Bangladesh (ICB) is facing a heavy loss of more than Tk 12.05 billion as it has been unable to recover any of the money invested in fixed deposit receipts (FDRs) with 12 troubled financial institutions. Of the institutions, 10 are non-bank financial institutions (NBFI
